Award.AwardTitle: Inclusion Barometry and Overstepping Isograd Reactions: How Close is the Approach to Equilibrium During Metamorphism?
Award.AbstractNarration:
The aim of the research outlined in this proposal is to examine and quantify the extent to which metamorphic rocks approach equilibrium during transformation. It is an accepted fact of all metamorphic transformations that some degree of overstepping of a reaction boundary is required in order for reactions to proceed in a forward direction. That is, rocks that are perfectly equilibrated will experience no driving force for recrystallization and will thus remain unchanged. Hence the mere existence of different degrees of metamorphic recrystallization under different conditions of pressure and temperature in the crust is evidence that transformations have, indeed, taken place and thus some degree of overstepping of reactions is required. However, it is also generally accepted that the degree of disequilibrium (overstepping) is minor such that a close approach to equilibrium is maintained throughout a rock?s history. This is the traditional justification for employing equilibrium phase diagrams for the interpretation of metamorphic conditions.

Part II.
This proposal seeks to evaluate the validity of the assumption of a close approach to equilibrium during metamorphism. Preliminary data is presented in the proposal that indicates a substantial deviation from equilibrium for the nucleation of the common metamorphic mineral, garnet. The amount of overstepping inferred from these preliminary studies varies in different samples from a few degrees Celsius to over seventy degrees and 5000 bars of pressure. Even more significant, the inferred conditions of garnet nucleation are very similar to the conditions inferred for the maximum metamorphic temperature and pressure attained by the sample. The implication of this result is that, rather than undergoing a continuum of small changes along a trajectory of increasing pressure and temperature in the crust, the rock remained virtually unchanged until reaching conditions near the maximum pressure and temperature and then transformed through a cascade of reactions.
This distinction is not merely academic. The assumption of a close approach to equilibrium during metamorphism has been the hallmark of metamorphic studies for over a century and nearly all of our understanding of the evolution of rocks during mountain building events and the inferred pressure and temperature conditions in the crust are based on this assumption. The preliminary results presented in this proposal imply that all of these previous inferences about conditions of metamorphism will need to be revised in light of these new findings. Furthermore, a cascade of metamorphic transformations occurring after significant overstepping has the potential to release copious amounts of fluids (e.g. H2O) into the crust, which has the potential for triggering substantial deformation. It is even suggested that deep, large magnitude earthquakes that are characteristic of subduction zones might be triggered by such a mechanism.
This study is made possible by a new technique by which the pressure (and possibly temperature) at which a mineral such as garnet forms can be determined by measuring the residual pressure of an inclusion of quartz, epidote, or zircon in the garnet by Raman spectroscopy. The assumption required by this new approach is that mechanical equilibrium is attained between the garnet and the inclusion. Comparison of the results from this new method with those that are obtained by assuming chemical equilibrium (the traditional approach) provides a quantitative measure of the degree of overstepping. The proposed study will evaluate the validity of this new technique through a series of experiments, apply the approach to well-characterized samples from well-studied mountain belts (e.g. in central New England), and develop new mineral inclusion-host pairs to extend the method to additional rock types.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary objective of this study was to evaluate the potential of a new technique to determine the pressure and temperature at which metamorphic rocks recrystallize. Mountain belts form when tectonic plates collide and the rocks caught up in the collision get deeply buried, heated, and undergo metamorphism. Determination of the conditions of metamorphism (the pressure (i.e. depth) and temperature) are the first order data required to develop models of this process. Why is this important? Many of our mineralogical natural resources (e.g. metals, gems, and economically important elements) are formed or concentrated by processes active during tectonic plate collisions so a deep understanding of these processes is essential for discovery and development of these resources.

            The traditional approach to determining the pressures and temperatures of metamorphic recrystallization assume that the mineral assemblages are very close to a state of chemical equilibrium. The conclusions that follow are all dependent on the validity of this assumption. There is clear evidence that many rocks form out of chemical equilibrium.  Our new technique is independent of the assumption of chemical equilibrium so it provides not only an estimate of the conditions of formation, but a means to evaluate how closely a rock approaches the equilibrium state.

            The method is based on the following premise. When a mineral such as garnet grows inside of a rock, room must be created for this new mineral. That process is not completely efficient and, as a result, pre-existing minerals are often trapped inside of the growing garnet. At the point at which a mineral is encased in the growing garnet, the size of the mineral exactly fits into the hole inside of the garnet. Subsequently, as the rock is exhumed back to Earth’s surface, both the garnet and the included mineral expand or contract in response to changing external temperature and pressure. Consequently, when the rock is examined in the laboratory, the inclusion no longer fits inside of the hole in the host garnet and will be under pressure that is different from the atmospheric pressure surrounding the garnet. The phenomenon is essentially the same as a tank of propane gas under pressure where the strength of the tank confines the gas and keeps it at higher pressure than atmospheric, although the process of formation is different. The pressure of the inclusion inside of garnet can be measured by a technique known as Raman spectroscopy (sort of like a pressure gauge). By measuring the pressure of the inclusion, our method can be used to infer the pressure at which the inclusion was trapped by applying a thermoelastic model that tracks how both the host and inclusion change size with changing temperature and pressure.

           Our work is divided into two parts. We have conducted experiments in which we have grown garnets with inclusions of quartz to test the method in a controlled environment. Our experiments confirm that the method works to provide accurate pressures to within a few percent of the experimental pressures. We have also applied this method to natural samples collected from a number of mountain belts worldwide, including classic metamorphic terranes in Scotland, New England, and the Alps, to high pressure rocks from Greece, Norway and Svalbard. In all cases we have found that the pressures of entrapment of the inclusions are far greater than those predicted by the calculations based on chemical equilibrium assumptions. That is, we have discovered that a considerable amount of overstepping of the equilibrium conditions are required for the nucleation and growth of a mineral such as garnet. This result has major implications for the interpretation of metamorphic processes. Firstly, it requires rethinking of all previous results about metamorphism that were based on the equilibrium assumption. Secondly, the pressure and hence depth of garnet formation are significantly deeper (often as much as 10 km deeper) than previously believed. Inasmuch as the formation of garnet also involves major release of fluids into the crust (fluids that might carry ore-forming elements), the depth of this major fluid generation is thus greater than was previously believed. In addition to being the critical transport mechanism for ore-forming processes, fluids flux melting in the crust and mantle and are the major factor in the eruption of volcanos and are also key agents in the lubrication of fault surfaces and can be the critical trigger in the generation of earthquakes. The implications of these findings are the subject of future work that directly relates to the evolution of magmas and earthquakes in regions of tectonic plate collisions.
